message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propranolol is a beta-blocker and can cause bradycardia and hypotension in overdose. Glucagon is a first-line treatment for beta-blocker toxicity and can increase heart rate and blood pressure. Atropine is not effective in treating beta-blocker toxicity. Adenosine and vagal maneuvers are used to treat supraventricular tachycardia, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propranolol is a beta-blocker, and overdose can lead to bradycardia and hypotension. Glucagon is a first-line treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it increases intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) levels, which can reverse the effects of beta-blockers. Atropine is not effective for bradycardia caused by beta-blockers. Adenosine is used for supraventricular tachycardias and vagal maneuvers are not effective for bradycardia caused by beta-blockers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing beta-blocker overdose and glucagon is the recommended first-line treatment. It works by stimulating glycogenolysis and increasing cAMP, thereby increasing heart rate and cardiac output. Atropine is not effective in this situation, adenosine is only used for supraventricular tachycardia, and vagal maneuvers would not be effective in treating beta-blocker overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propranolol overdose can cause bradycardia and hypotension, and glucagon is the first line treatment as it increases cAMP and counteracts the effects of beta-blockers. Atropine is used for bradyarrhythmias but may not be effective in this case. Adenosine and vagal maneuvers are used for tachyarrhythmias.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propranolol overdose can cause bradycardia and hypotension, and among the options, only glucagon can increase heart rate and blood pressure. Glucagon increases cAMP in the cardiac tissue, which can cause positive inotropic and chronotropic effects. Atropine is used for bradycardia but not for overdose of propranolol. Adenosine and vagal maneuvers are used for supraventricular tachycardia, which is not the case here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can cause bradycardia and hypotension when taken in large amounts. Glucagon is a first-line treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it increases intracellular cAMP and enhances calcium influx, which counteracts beta-blockade. Atropine is used for bradycardia caused by cholinergic drugs, adenosine is used for supraventricular tachycardia, and vagal maneuvers are used for certain types of arrhythmias.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has overdosed on propanolol, which is a beta-blocker. Glucagon is the first-line treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it increases cyclic AMP and improves contractility and heart rate. Atropine, adenosine, and vagal maneuvers are not effective in treating beta-blocker overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propanolol is a beta-blocker, and glucagon is the first-line treatment for beta-blocker overdose. Atropine is used for bradycardia, while adenosine and vagal maneuvers are used for supraventricular tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest beta-blocker overdose, and among the options, Glucagon is the first line treatment for beta-blocker overdose. It increases cAMP levels and increases cardiac output. Atropine is not effective in beta-blocker overdose. Adenosine is used to treat supraventricular tachycardia, while vagal maneuvers can be used in some arrhythmias, but are not effective in beta-blocker overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Propanolol is a beta-blocker and overdosing can cause bradycardia and hypotension. Glucagon is a first-line treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it increases intracellular cAMP and reverses the effects of beta-blockers on myocardial contractility and AV node conduction. Atropine, adenosine, and vagal maneuvers are not effective in treating beta-blocker overdose.
